messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> Do not use Math.random() directly. Instead, hide it behind an
interface that provides a method like "getNextNumber()". In your
tests, substitute an implementation that answers an expected sequence
of numbers. Give this method as good a name as you can think of, given
your problem domain.

I tend to use java.util.Random. Either pass in an instance of Random,
or use a factory method to generate one. If you pass it it you can
make a specialization of Random that returns a deterministic/canned
sequence. If you use a factory method, you'll have to also specialize
the class being tested to override teh factory method so as to return
a specialized Random. Here's an example (I replaced indentation
spaces with periods as yahoo seems not to handle leading spaces well
in my experience):

final int [] randomValues = {3, 5, 1, 2, 4, 0 };
Random fakeRandom = new Random() {
....int index = 0;
....public int nextInt(int n) {
........int result = randomValues[index];
........index = (index + 1) % randomValues.length;
........return result;
....}
};
aGame.orderPlayers(fakeRandom);

I could have done this as an anonymous class as well.. directly as the
argument.

Dave
